On 11/12/05, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> Colin, about=
 your suggestion #2: Joseph Reisinger has done some
> interesting work on v=
arying the fitness function in order to get a
> more robust genetic encodin=
g.  The idea is that if the fitness
> function varies but there is some und=
erlying theme that is conserved
> (such as symmetry) the organisms will nee=
d to evolve to be able to
> represent that underlying theme efficiently eve=
n though they can't
> rely on any particular instance of it.  This does imp=
ly that
> calamities can lead to robustness, but it appears than an importa=
nt
> ingredient in such a system is an encoding that can encapsulate
> info=
rmation about underlying themes, i.e. an indirect encoding.
> Here's the pa=
per:
>
> http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?reisinger:gecco05
>
> ken

I'm sud=
denly reminded of something.  I read recently about some
experiments that w=
ere done with various metals in solution.  They
would let them bleed up som=
e paper, and photograph the results. 
Interestingly enough, the results var=
ied with things you wouldn't
expect:  The postions of the sun and moon!  Th=
e location of the sun
and moon relative to the earth greatly influenced the=
 way the
molecules behaved.  Well, greatly is relative...

Point is, though=
, that those molecules are a part of biological
systems.  Which means that =
they behave slightly differently depending
on the time of month.  There is,=
 in nature, a slowly cycling
'alteration' of behavior at a chemical level. =
 That could easily
explain the anecdotally observed 'craziness' that occurs=
 during a full
moon.

So perhaps this idea of altering the landscape might =
be a great
idea...  It may be something that nature herself employs.  Small=
,
subtle, but real.

Brings me back to our discussion before, of having del=
iberate but
small random perturbations in the network that forces it to dev=
elop a
more robust solution to the problem...
